A numerical research of wideband solar absorber based on refractory metal from visible to near infrared
Peiqi Yua,c, Xifang Chena,c, Zao Yia,c,∗, Yongjian Tanga,c, Hua Yangb, Zigang Zhoua,c, Tao Duana,c, Shubo Chengd, Jianguo Zhange, Yougen Yif
a Joint Laboratory for Extreme Conditions Matter Properties, Southwest University of Science and Technology, Mianyang, 621010, China b State Key Laboratory of Advanced Processing and Recycling of Non-ferrous Metals, Lanzhou University of Technology, Lanzhou, 730050, China c Sichuan Civil-Military Integration Institute, Mianyang, 621010, China d School of Physics and Optoelectronic Engineering, Yangtze University, Jingzhou, Hubei, 434023, China e Institute of Theoretical Physics, State Key Laboratory of Quantum Optics and Quantum Optics Devices, Shanxi University, Taiyuan, 030006, China f College of Physics and Electronics, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Solar absorber Wideband absorption Refractory Plasmon resonance
A B S T R A C T
The range of solar radiation observed on Earth is about 295–2500 nm. Designing the absorber within this range allows it to obtain as long an absorption band as possible to help alleviate energy problems. In this paper, a refractory metal material is theoretically designed to have an efficiency in designing an absorber with broadband solar absorption, and using FDTD method to numerically simulate it. The absorber achieves broadband absorption in the visible-near-infrared range, absorbing an absorption bandwidth of A> 90% up to 1264 nm (0.36 μm - 1624 μm). The absorption spectrum of the absorber can be manipulated by adjusting the structural parameters. More importantly, solar absorbers composed of TiO2 and TiN have higher thermal stability than nano resonators composed of conventional metal materials. Moreover, such an absorber does not reduce the absorption of solar radiation in the case where the angle of incidence changes.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Solar energy has become one of the most important candidates to solve the energy crisis because of its clean and renewable nature. But to make efficient use of solar energy, feasible and durable electromagnetic wave absorbers are needed to capture solar energy. Electromagnetic wave absorber can be traced back to 1902, when Wood [1] first discovered SPR (Surface plasmon resonance) in an optical experiment. Subsequently, the plasmonic perfect absorber [2–6] has aroused great interest due to its unique subwavelength light trapping ability and potential application in solar energy harvesting.
In 2008, Landy [2] first reported an ideal electromagnetic wave absorber based on metal-insulator-metal (MIM) three-layer element material. Plasmonic absorber is usually formed by metal-insulatormetal three-layer structure, and normally generates single resonance absorption peak according to size of absorber [7–9]. Researchers have a great interest in absorber due to its wide range of applications in energy harvesting, light-emitting diodes, sensing, optical filters and photocatalysis [10–16]. Precious metals have also been widely used in these perfect absorbers due to their plasmon resonance and optical coupling
behavior [17], but they are expensive and have low reserves. At the same time, these single formant can not meet the need of wide spectrum high absorption of solar absorber. Even with continuous MIM thin film stacks, most traditional three-layer continuous MIM thin film stacks have limited absorption bandwidth in the visible region, such as 400–800 nm [18], followed by a variety of solar absorbers based on other materials [19–26]. For solar energy absorbers, to collect solar energy, the absorption bandwidth must be broadened. One way to solve this problem is to combine different sizes of nano-resonators in a single cycle to reach the broadband absorption [27]. In recent years, many people have carried out this process, but its production process is generally complex and inefficient [28,29]. And because the nano-resonators that can be placed in the space unit are limited, this method of expanding the absorption bandwidth of the absorber is very limited. Another approach is to utilized benign plasmon behavior of refractory metals discovered in recent years [30]. These refractory metal materials can provide a wide-band absorption response due to their inherent absorption losses in the wide-band [31]. Titanium is one of the best refractory materials, its chemical properties are stable at room temperature, and it has many advantages over precious metals widely used

in absorbers. Its high reserves are 16 times the total amount of copper, nickel, lead and zinc, so the cost is low. Besides, due to the large loss of the imaginary part of the dielectric constant, titanium and its composite materials have been explored to have strong plasmon resonance behavior [32–34], which can solve the problem of short absorption spectrum prevalent in absorbers using noble metals. The high melting point of titanium and its composites makes it more advantageous to work in higher temperature environments [34–36]. Moreover, the process is simpler and has more potential than the former method. Through a large number of studies on the optical and electrical properties of TiN, it is found that electron collision with TiN structure or nano resonator can produce high energy electron or thermionic under the energetic or the hot electrons [37,38]. Based on the characteristics of this refractory metal, solar absorber and solar-related thermal photovoltaic, solar thermoelectric generator and heat transfer systemhave been greatly improved compared with traditional devices [39–43]. Recently Liu et al. have made Ti based wideband perfect optical absorbers, in which the absorption is greater than 90% on the continuous spectrum with a width of 1007 nm and the maximum is 97.5% [44]. With a wider absorption spectrum and a higher average absorption, the absorber can perform better in the fields of thermal radiation, thermal photoelectric and energy collection.
In our study, TiO2–TiN nano-elliptical disk arrays designed by us was used to obtain wideband absorption. Due to the structure used to reduce reflection and obstructs transmission, we can achieve absorption of more than 90% in the 1264 nm band in the visible-near infrared spectrum of about 450 nm after numerical simulation by FDTD (the Finite Difference Time Domain) method, and the average absorption can reach 95.68%. The average absorption rate can reach 95.68%. In addition, the absorption is insensitive to the oblique incidence of light. At the same time, because of the use of refractory materials, in the solar radiation has a strong practicality and higher heat resistance, so that the whole solar energy absorber than the traditional metal higher heat resistance, stability, corrosion resistance and high hardness.

sections.heading: 2. Structure and design of broadband perfect absorber
sections.text:
The structure diagram is shown in Fig. 1(a) and Fig. 1(b). Each cycle is consisted of an elliptical TiN plate and a TiO2 elliptical plate of the same size. The thickness of top elliptic plate is H1]H2=65 nm, Semimajor axis is C= 130 nm and semi-minor axis is D=60 nm. The
structural parameters of TiN nano-elliptical plate in the next layer are the same as those in the previous layer. The substrate of the periodic elliptical disk arrays pattern is constituted by a SiO2 and a TiN with a thickness of H3]H4=100 nm,respectively, and the length of a single period is 360 nm. TiN is a major contributor to the optical coupling and absorption in the range of visible-near infrared light due to its plasmon characteristics [45–47]. TiN material itself has high flame retardant.Melting point is up to 3200 K, with high structural strength, suitable for high-power, high-temperature operation and stability [35]. TiO2 is a widely used medium with high refractive index and strong plasmon resonance [42]. In this structure, the lowest layer of TiN is reflecting substrate. It is thick enough to reflect all the wavelengths of light studied. We used the FDTD method to numerically simulate the absorption mechanism and optical properties of the absorber [48]. To reduce computation time and server memory, the array mode is implemented using periodic boundary conditions in the x and y directions, respectively. The perfect matching layer can be directly adopted in the z direction outside the structure area, and mesh accuracy is set to level 6, which is high precision. And the planar source used is from 0.25 to 3 μm. Using the experimental data of Ref [49], the dielectric constant of the titanium-based composite material is obtained. The refractive index of SiO2 is 1.45. The transmitted light spectrum is detected at the bottom of the absorber in the z direction, and a detector is set above the light source in the z direction to detect the reflection spectrum. In these conditions, we can study the nano resonator optical transmission, reflection and absorption characteristics.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
As shown in Fig. 1(c), R is the transmitted light intensity, T is the reflected light intensity, and A is the light absorption. A is defined as A=1-R-T [50–52]. In the whole spectrum range, the transmission is close to 0, which indicates that the TiN structure completely suppresses the transmission. For reflection, it is controlled at a very low level in a wide range. As a result of the interaction of that, broad-spectrum absorption is obtained. If A>90% is used as perfect absorption broadband, the wavelength is 0.36–1.624 μm, and the wavelength width is 1264 nm. That is to say, the visible-near infrared region is the perfect absorption band. When the wavelength is 0.8612 μm and 1.333 μm, the maximum absorption is 99.3%.
Fig. 2 shows the distribution of resonant electric field, where resonance occurs at the highest absorption and lowest reflection. At lambda=0.380 μm, the electric field is predominantly located in the direction of polarization on the back of the TiN nano-elliptical disk and the surface of the TiO2 nano-elliptical disk. At the wavelength λ=0.830 μm, a strong electric field is observed along the polarization direction of the rear side of the TiN nano-elliptical disk. Meanwhile, for the λ=0.830 μm, it can be seen that a partial electric field is in the TiN nano-elliptical disk. A significant field distribution is shown in the region near the top TiO2 nano resonator. These phenomena show that the dipole couples the optical cavity modes of TiN nano-elliptical disk and the top of its TiO2 nano resonator. At the lowest point of reflection is at λ=1.380 μm, the back of the TiN nano-elliptical disk only be measured very strong electric field distribution, indicating that the TiN nano resonator is excited by the plasmon dipole mode [49]. The light field distribution of these resonators indicates that the plasmon resonance of the nano resonator and its hybrid coupling effect play an important role in wideband light absorption.
In Fig. 3 (a), the basis of this structure is the same as previous work. The substrate formed of TiN film in the lower layer and SiO2 layer in the upper layer, and the structural parameters are the same as before. Above the substrate is a single TiN nano-elliptical disk array. Since the transmission is T~0, the absorption is defined as A=1-R. Fig. 3(a) shows the absorption spectrum. For this TiN nano-elliptical disk arrays absorber, two absorption peaks appear. The absorption of the first absorption peak is 96.9% at the wavelength λ=0.690 μm. The
absorption of the second absorption peak is 96.5% at the wavelength λ=1.33 μm. Compared with the wideband absorption spectrum of the nano-elliptical disk arrays composed by TiO2 and TiN, the absorption spectrum coverage of a single TiN nano-elliptical disk arrays is much smaller. Two electric field peaks in the absorption spectrum is shown in Fig. 3 (a), the both are substantially restricted to the back of the elliptical disk, elliptical disk support which showed TiN resonance plasmon resonance. Fig. 3 (b) shows the spectral diagram of the absorber with only TiO2 nano-elliptical disk on the substrate. It can be observed that the absorption decreases sharply in a short wavelength range, which also testify to that TiO2 can only achieve high absorption in a very narrow wavelength range. The first absorption peak is at wavelength of 0.3596 μm and the absorption is 94.6%. The strong magnetic field is above the elliptical disk, and the electric field is also seen on the back of the elliptical disk, which demonstrates that the TiO2 nano-elliptical disk had obvious optical diffraction behavior and optical resonance. The absorption of peak at 0.8332 μm is 55%. There is an evident electric field on the back of TiO2 nano-elliptical disk, which indicated plasmon dipole resonance of TiO2 nano-elliptical disk. Through the study of a single TiO2 nano-elliptical disk or a single TiN nano-elliptical disk, it is found that the absorption spectrum effect of a single TiN nano-elliptical disk is not good in the region with short wavelength (0.32 μm–0.41 μm). In the longer wavelength coverage (0.53 μm–1.6 μm), the same is true for a single TiO2 nano-elliptical disk. When TiN nano-elliptical disk and TiO2 nano-elliptical disk are combined together, their spectral absorption response is definitely complementary, which can eventually form the broad spectrum absorption.
We try to adjust the parameters of the absorber to go into different structure parameters on the influence of the absorption spectra of the absorber. Fig. 4(a) is an absorption spectrum in which the Semimajor axis of the TiO2–TiN nano-elliptical disk arrays increases from 110 nm to 150 nm. The longer the semi-long axis, the wider the ideal absorption
band. This phenomenon is mainly due to the strong optical coupling efficiency of a larger resonator at a longer wavelength [53]. With precious metal nanoparticles [54] plasmon response similar to that of refractory metal plate also follows the basic relations of the resonance wavelength and the structure size [55]. However, the absorption between the two absorption peaks with shorter wavelength increases gradually. The reason for this phenomenon is mainly that the optical coupling efficiency of the TiO2 elliptical disk is increased, resulting in an increase in absorption between the two absorption peaks. The absorption gradually decreases between the longer absorption peaks of the two wavelengths. This may be caused by the separation of adjacent resonance absorption peaks caused by different structural parameters [56]. In Fig. 4(b), a similar phenomenon occurs when the semi-minor axis of the elliptical disk is increased from 40 nm to 80 nm, but the effect is not as significant as in Fig. 4(a). Although these absorbers exhibit a wide range of perfect absorption bands under these structural parameters, a balance must be obtained between absorption bandwidth and high absorption to obtain better results.
Next, the influences of different polarization angles and incident angles on the absorption spectrum of the absorber were investigated. As Fig. 5(a) shows, under the condition that the incident angle increases, the high absorption portion of the absorption spectrum obviously starts to expand at about 20°. This suggests that the nano resonator and effective coupling of oblique electromagnetic wave scope has been broadened. In general, the different angles of incident light substantially no effect on the absorption spectrum of the absorber. In Fig. 5(b), the absorber does not perform well at absorption under different polarized conditions, but still maintains high absorption in the visible region. After the polarized light exceeds 30°, the closer to the TE polarized light, the higher the absorption portion of the absorption spectrum begins to narrow. It is not difficult to understand because surface plasmon resonance is generally pretty susceptive to different
polarization [57]. In general, the absorber continues to keep a high absorption at incident light at different angles. Although polarized light has an effect on the absorption of the absorber, it still maintains a high absorption in the visible region. This basically satisfies the need as a solar absorber. The solar absorber must have the ability to operate at high temperatures, so the absorption spectrum of the absorber at temperatures from 273 K to 1000 K is simulated in Fig. 5(c). We can see that the change in temperature has no effect on its absorption spectrum, indicating that it also has very good effects at high temperatures. There may be interfacial diffusion and potential oxidation between the various structures of the solar absorber at high temperatures [58,59]. However, this paper is mainly a numerical simulation, which is not within the scope of this article.
As a kind of solar energy absorber, it is necessary to study the absorption of solar radiation by the absorber. As shown in Fig. 6(a), by calculating the absorption of solar energy by the simulated absorber in the AM1.5 spectrum [60], it can be found that the absorber can gain nearly ideal wideband absorption in the range of visible-near infrared
light. And in the wavelength coverage of high absorption corresponds to the high energy part of the main solar radiation. Fig. 6(b) shows the distribution of solar energy absorbed and losted of the absorber. We can see that there is still some solar energy lost, but the absorption rate remains very high. It can be seen that the absorber has inherent advantages in the resonance absorption of solar energy in the visible - near infrared band.

sections.heading: 4. conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, we designed TiO2–TiN nano-elliptical disk arrays as a solar absorber and numerically simulate it using the FDTD method. The TiO2–TiN nano-elliptical disk arrays structure simultaneously provides a variety of resonance modes, and a plurality of resonance modes are strongly coupled with sunlight, thereby obtaining broad spectrum absorption. It can be obtained that the absorber can realize broad spectrum absorption with an absorption greater than 90% in the range of visible-near infrared light 1264 nm, and the average absorption is
95.68%. It can be seen from the results that the absorber is insensitive to the absorption of incident light at different angles, and the influence of different polarized lights on the absorber is explored. Finally, this solar absorber is proved to have excellent performance by calculating the absorption of sunlight.

metadata.abstractText: The range of solar radiation observed on Earth is about 295–2500 nm. Designing the absorber within this range allows it to obtain as long an absorption band as possible to help alleviate energy problems. In this paper, a refractory metal material is theoretically designed to have an efficiency in designing an absorber with broadband solar absorption, and using FDTD method to numerically simulate it. The absorber achieves broadband absorption in the visible-near-infrared range, absorbing an absorption bandwidth of A> 90% up to 1264 nm (0.36 μm 1624 μm). The absorption spectrum of the absorber can be manipulated by adjusting the structural parameters. More importantly, solar absorbers composed of TiO2 and TiN have higher thermal stability than nano resonators composed of conventional metal materials. Moreover, such an absorber does not reduce the absorption of solar radiation in the case where the angle of incidence changes.
